No experience is required, just readiness to jump in. You‚Äôll meet people, learn activities that you can take back to your teams/families/friends, practice and reflect on a variety of skills, and walk out full of joy and energy. Come play with us!
tags: improv, games, communication

title: Macrotasking: How expensive is your CSS?
body:
When was the last time you measured how much your application's CSS bundle cost your users to download?

A non-zero percentage of people using your or your company's products pay for their internet by the byte. This is an especially stark truth for people in developing nations. Efforts towards reducing bundle sizes and improving caching strategies are not only good technical practice, but good ethical and business practice as well.

In this session, I will illustrate, using real numbers, costs, and stories, the realities of making a living in developing nations working for some of the biggest names in AI and ML. I'll connect industry best practices in managing static assets to the people those practices benefit, identifying win-win opportunities for you, your product, and your communities.
tags: CSS, ROI, Empathy, CI/CD

title: How games can inspire great application UX
body:
What makes a great UX for games and what does it mean for mobile applications?

I interviewed Raph Koster, the famous game designer and author of 'The Theory of Fun' about his principles of game design. I was convinced games and apps were two different worlds and there was little to borrow except maybe come cool graphic animation tricks.

Raph completely destroyed my arguments. This talk is my journey into the light. How I learned that at a very deep level, there is little different between great games and great apps. 

I'll present 6 basic principles of game design and show how each can be applied to app UX design in meaningful ways.

An early trial version of this talk was given both at the game research group at Swansea University and internally at Google. The feedback from these versions have caused me to heavily revise and rewrite the talk.
tags: UX, Games

title: Tester at the Table and the Tester in my Head
body:
The relationship between software developers and quality assurance professionals is crucial to making good products. Through 15 years of software development, Adrian P. Dunston has had opportunities to work with dedicated and talented QA professionals. And now he has a little tester in his head.

So how do we build up the little testers in our heads? Based on extensive reading and years of working with and without the support of QA professionals, Adrian will show you:

* How to help your QA team-members be force multipliers
* How to become and encourage quality-minded developers 
* How to use repetition and story to get your ideas stuck your colleague's heads
* How to instill habits they can use and take with them
tags: quality,relationships,communication

title: What we learned from getting 100% of our engineers on-call
body: This is a talk about scaling engineering culture, disguised as a talk about sustainable on-call rotations in the age of microservices. It is a report on Duolingo‚Äôs journey to an on-call ecosystem that includes every single one of our 80+ engineers and on the development of the ‚Äúon-call pain balancer‚Äù, which automatically generates rotations based on team composition, service maturity, and incident statistics. We will share some of the tools and processes that have helped us reduce the burden of being on-call, and how setting out to standardize a single aspect of engineering life opened the door to a much deeper conversation and taught us lessons that went far beyond improving site reliability.
tags: on-call, microservices, scaling, engineering culture, work-life balance, documentation

title: From Software Craftsman to Product Owner
body:
Many start-ups are driven by an entrepreneur who is a subject matter expert looking for a technical co-founder.

This is a story of a software craftsman who unwittingly became as subject matter expert due to his sons interest in American Ninja Warrior and subsequent success in the related sport.  He quickly saw the need for software that would help run events more efficiently and effectively.  So, he decided to birth a Software-as-a-Service with his high-performance, multi-disciplinary team.

He‚Äôll walk through the story of how the SaaS evolved from concept to the standard for the major organizations in the sport in roughly a year‚Äôs time.  He‚Äôll punctuate the advantages and disadvantages of being a Product Owner who had previously always been on the side of the technical team.
tags: Object-Oriented JavaScript, HTML Canvas, Software Craftsmanship, Designers, Developers, 2D, 3D, Visualization

title: You (yes you) need to support junior developers
body:
"We just can't find all of the developers that we need to build our product"
"Here's a promising developer, right out of code school, why don't you hire her?"
"Oh, we don't hire junior developers. Because $REASONS."

Life as a new developer can be frustrating, especially for one coming out of something other than a big-name Computer Science program. They hear about the shortage of developers in the industry, but often find it extremely difficult to get that first job. However, if there are no junior developers, there will eventually be no senior developers. Frequently, companies do not know how to successfully integrate new developers, and the developers lack the experience and confidence to understand their needs. So how can your team be part of the solution?

In this session, you will hear from a longtime hiring manager/CTO, who has hired at all experience levels for remote and in-office development teams, and who has successfully onboard and supported entry-level developers at several companies. They will discuss several areas where teams stumble in effectively supporting new developers, and provide actionable techniques that your company can use to make the most of valuable talent out on the job market.

It's a cutthroat market for development talent out there. If your company can find and grow new developers when your competitors cannot, you will end up ahead of the game. Plus, you will be helping the future of the industry. Come learn how.

title: Finding People: Job Posting Strategies
body:
Collaborative software development needs amazing, curious and thoughtful people, but we aren't very good at broadcasting what we need in our job descriptions. Many job postings seem to have been cut and paste from an older posting or even from another company's posting. The tech industry has a surplus of openings, but many companies -- especially in the free and open source software space -- are still competing for the same small pool of workers. 

Getting your job postings in front of people who are outside that small pool starts with writing an amazing and thoughtful job description and then doing some creative thinking about where you post it. If you're looking to diversify your workplace, you'll probably have to examine some existing assumptions about who will be "a good fit" or how your tasks are divided up. Highly skilled workers have choices about how to spend their days, and they do not have time for companies that treat them like cogs in a machine. Respect your potential applicants and you will find that they will respect your company enough to come work for you, and grow with you, and help your project succeed.
tags: job postings, tech workers, people

title: Imposter Syndrome - Why did they let me come up here and talk to you?
body:
What am I doing here? All these people are so much smarter than me. They‚Äôll find out I have no idea what I‚Äôm talking about. Why did they even let me do this in the first place? I should‚Äôve just stayed at my last job. Sure, I hated it, but I knew how to do it. 

Sound familiar? You might have Imposter Syndrome. Imposter Syndrome is a very, very common issue that a lot of us face. In the ever-growing world of tech, it sometimes seems difficult to both get and keep up to speed on what‚Äôs going on in your company. Especially for those of us that are career-changers, the task sometimes seems even more daunting.

In this talk, we‚Äôll examine Imposter Syndrome and learn how to nip it in the bud! We‚Äôll learn techniques for recognizing and squashing those imposter-y feelings before you let it take over your life and career.
tags: soft skills, imposter syndrome

title: Using AI to Build More Secure Software
body: MITRE's growing Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) list -- nearly 150,000 and growing -- is testament that building software that is resistant and resilient to attack remains difficult. The introduction of SecDevOps looks to improve security of software but has not taken advantage of how artificial intelligence could be used to improve the security of software. This presentation will discuss why the construction of secure software is a concern beyond the IT industry, the elements of a secure software development process and how artificial intelligence could be applied to improve that process. The discussion will then consider additional security issues facing the construction of artificial intelligence software.

title: Architecture and Organization
body: Drawing on real-life examples from Avvo, Spotify, Adobe and Microsoft, Kevin Goldsmith explores why you should consider changing your organization to improve your architecture and discusses the successes and failures he‚Äôs seen around the interplay of organizational models and software architectures. Kevin often visits companies, where he hears about how they struggle to break up monolithic applications or move to a continuous deployment pipeline. Oftentimes, the organizational structure is clearly making their problems harder but is seen as something that can‚Äôt be changed. Kevin relates his own journey to a more experimental organizational style. As a developer at Microsoft, Kevin worked in a rigid hierarchy organized around functional areas. The communication flows within the organization dictated the way it structured its libraries and dependencies. This is the essence of Conway‚Äôs law. In this case, the company hierarchy and the architecture it produced was often suboptimal for the problem Kevin and his team were solving, but it was the architectural path of least resistance. When Kevin moved to Adobe and became a senior manager, he started to build his organization in the traditional way. Adobe wanted to create a more fluid and agile architecture for its products, but the company struggled to realize these goals because it was it was too hard to work across teams and reporting lines. The company finally started to make some progress as the organization became more fluid and loosely coupled. Kevin then went to Spotify, which had realized this problem early on and restructured its organization in a way that supported the architectural model that it wanted to build. As a vice president of engineering, Kevin was able to see firsthand how the organizational model simplified the architectural challenges that other companies struggled with while also introducing difficulties that other companies were easily able to overcome. When Kevin joined Avvo as its CTO, the company had the same organization and architectural challenges as many other startups, but rather than attack them only from an architectural angle, Avvo experimented with architecture and organization together to improve its legacy systems and help build new ones faster and with higher quality.
tags: software architecture, organization design, culture

title: All! The! New! Things!: Using MVVM, Flow-Coordinators, and RxSwift to create a completely dynamic UI
body: It seems like everyone is talking about reactive programming and architecture, but it can be difficult to figure how or why to use these tools to actually benefit your work. Faced with the challenge of creating an app with a completely dynamic UI under ever-changing scope and deadlines, my team was able to use MVVM, Flow-coordinators, and RxSwift to adapt to change, manage risk, and tame the chaos. In this talk, we'll discuss the specific problems that each of these frameworks and patterns helped to solve, lessons learned from implementing so many new tools on a single project, and what to consider before using these tools in your own projects.
tags: frameworks, design patterns, mvvm, rxswift, reactive programming, coordinators, mobile, swift, ios

title: Practical Open Source Security
body:
While 81% of users feel that developers are responsible for security, open source maintainers only rate their own security knowledge as 6.6/10(1). Whether you‚Äôre creating, maintaining, or depending on open source software, you have a responsibility to code with a secure mindset and educate yourself on the minimum steps needed to properly secure your open source projects.

This talk will cover open source security management from both a proactive and reactive standpoint. We'll start with a basic understanding of the top web application security risks, dive in to monitoring and auditing best practices, take a tour of available tools and walk through how to automate the detection of insecure patterns and outdated libraries affected by known vulnerabilities.

You'll leave with actionable steps secure your open source code with confidence.

1. https://res.cloudinary.com/snyk/image/upload/v1551172581/The-State-Of-Open-Source-Security-Report-2019-Snyk.pdf
tags: open source, security, code management, devsecops

title: That time I accidentally built a sweatshop
body:
When we build software we build experiences, and with that comes ethical responsibility. The poster child for these dilemmas might be variable reward consumer apps, but software for work is even worse! How often do your tools make you angry? How often do they dictate how you work and take away your professional autonomy?

In this talk I'll explore my experiences building software for the workplace, the ethical lessons I've learnt, and some of the hidden ethical problems in features of the software you use every day.
tags: ethics,saas

title: Debugging our Feelings: Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for Developers
body:
Developers have countless frameworks and tools to tackle technical problems but what can we use when we face personal ones? This talk is an introduction to cognitive behavioural therapy, which provides practical techniques to help change how we feel by changing how we think.

Through simple programming analogies, you'll learn:
1. What cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is
2. Why the model it offers fits so well with our developer mindset
3. How CBT can be applied to help deal with challenges like procrastination, perfectionism, impostor syndrome, and handling criticism
4. How to turn a piece of paper into a powerful debugger for our thoughts
tags: mental health, self-care, cognitive behavioural therapy, procrastination, perfectionism, impostor syndrome

title: From Robotium to Appium: Choose your Journey
body:
Mobile Testing is hard! You have to test not only Native Mobile but also Web-based applications. This multi-platform focus makes the testing effort to be at least twice as complicated as when a simple web application is targeted.

With the growing market around smartphones, developers needed more ways to ensure software quality of their product. This need is why many mobile UI test frameworks have been introduced. With the most significant share of the mobile market being taken by Android OS, development and testing efforts have been especially crucial in this ecosystem.

Among the variety of Mobile UI automation tools, two frameworks have been especially notable: Robotium and Appium. However, with more organizations moving towards multi-platform solutions, those of us, who used Robotium, are slowly moving towards Appium. This journey from Robotium to Appium is where the main focus of this presentation lies.

In this session, we deep dive into both Robotium and Appium. We discuss why and how to transition from Robotium to Appium in the Android ecosystem. Lastly, we look at common mistakes made during this transition, and how to avoid them.
tags: mobile,testing

title: The White Glove Treatment: Polishing Your iOS Build with Jenkins
body: We use continuous integration and delivery systems to help us build apps all the time. Our pull requests trigger builds that we can test, merging them triggers other builds that we can deploy, and so on. What about all of the other tedious tasks involved in development? This talk will cover using Jenkins, fastlane, and other tools as a system to automatically update an iOS app's dependencies‚Äîwhether you use CocoaPods, Carthage, or the Swift Package Manager‚Äîprovide inline feedback on pull requests, and manage tedious distribution work. By the end, you'll have tools at your disposal to let Jenkins do the tedious part of app development, letting you take care of what's actually important.
tags: iOS, automation, CI, Jenkins, fastlane, CocoaPods, Carthage, Swift, Swift Package Manager

title: Overcoming Challenges: An Attitude of Iteration
body: Challenges are a very real part of daily life. Some challenges are very apparent, like having one finger on each hand. Other challenges, are less apparent but no less of a hurdle that must be jumped. As someone who was born different and has been challenged through life, I have a very interesting view on hitting challenges head on. I also like to laugh as I deal with these challenges. In this session I we will joke our way through having an attitude of iteration in how we deal with challenges in our personal lives AND in our work lives. Prepare to laugh, commiserate, and face your challenges!
tags: Challenges, Laughter, Comedy

title: Consider The Pattern
body:
Software design is hard. That‚Äôs why we invented design patterns. Design patterns abstract common approaches to problem solving into generic approaches that can be modified to suit the application at hand.

Many of the design patterns in common use today are inspired by static object-oriented Enterprise languages like Java and C++. These languages have a feature set that is somewhat more restrictive than the languages that came after them, and many design patterns are built to provide elegant ways around these restrictions.

Design patterns, like Dependency Injection, and the Singleton pattern arise from restrictions on how you can pass code around at runtime. The Visitor Pattern arose from a need to safely traverse data structures. Other patterns, like Iterators and Factories, have been replaced by first-class language features of their own.

In this talk, we‚Äôll build up several design patterns, and then look at features in newer languages, and newer versions of languages that make each pattern unnecessary. In doing so, you‚Äôll get a view into idiomatically designing code in your favourite language, and a greater understanding of design decisions users of other languages need to make.
tags: python, kotlin, java, design patterns, patterns, object-oriented programming, programming, architecture

title: MUD to OOP: An Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming in Online RPGs
body:
Text-based online multi-user dungeons, or ‚ÄúMUDs‚Äù have been around since the 1980s, and are still popular in 2019. Based on Dungeons & Dragons, MUDs offer an interactive roleplaying experience, without the manual work of the tabletop game.

They taught me about the concept of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP), long before I even knew what it was. Objects are used for virtually every aspect, from players and objects, to rooms and the non-playable characters we ‚Äúfight‚Äù.

In my talk, I'm going to provide some actual examples of MUD objects, represented in JavaScript!

By bridging the concepts of classes, attributes, and methods with object models in MUDs, new and experienced coders alike can better understand how objects interact, and the problems that objects solve in games.
tags: javascript, object oriented programming, gaming

title: Code & Fabrication
body:
One hundred and ninety-five speakers, four hundred and fifty suspended glass orbs and a fifty-three-foot long hallway; what do all these things have in common? Technology. Computationally designed, CNC cut, hand assembled, running code across sixty-eight computers these three examples of interactive art represent how technology and fabrication play nice to create something exceptional.

This talk will look at lessons from working in the physical world with digital tools and how this intersection creates a challenging set of problems, the solutions to which always lead to a better result. There is a lot to be learned in writing code or designing electronics that go in strange and weird places.
tags: code, hardware, electronics, fabrication, making, design

title: Artistic Style Transfer with Convolutional Neural Networks
body:
Style transfer is a unique technique for creating computer-generated art that repurposes deep neural networks originally trained for image classification. It‚Äôs the magic behind apps like Prisma that combine famous paintings and photos to produce pastiches that mimic the artistic style. In this talk, we‚Äôll take a look at the ideas behind this surprisingly simple algorithm and introduce fundamental Machine Learning and Deep Learning concepts along the way. Topics will include:

‚Ä¢ A high-level introduction to neural networks and deep convolutional nets for Computer Vision.
‚Ä¢ An overview of the original style transfer algorithm and related concepts like optimization.
‚Ä¢ A review of new ‚Äòfast‚Äô architectures for running style transfer in real-time.
‚Ä¢ Resources for learning more about ML/DL and Computer Vision.
tags: machine learning, deep learning, computer vision, computer-generated art

title: Developers Should Not Become Managers (unless they should)
body:
Too often, developers move into management roles for the wrong reasons and without adequate preparation. The erroneous view that management represents a promotion for developers causes mismatched expectations and undue stress on new managers and their teams. We need to talk about what management really is and why it's so difficult for developers to succeed. If you've ever thought about becoming a manager or are afraid you may one day be forced to, come hear what it's really like so you can make an informed decision about where to take your career.

As a developer-turned-manager, Jamie has stumbled over enough of the hurdles making the transition to clearly explain why you should absolutely not follow the same path he did (unless maybe you should).
tags: management, career

title: Modern Application Delivery with AWS, Azure and HashiCorp
body:
The compatibility between AWS, Azure and HashiCorp tools is very mature, with many production deployments to learn from. In this talk we will demo multiple workflows that have worked well for both AWS and Azure users who utilize HashiCorp tools.  Popular cloud services combined with HashiCorp tools can help you build a reliable application delivery platform.  This talk includes demos for:

Vagrant - Developer environment provisioning
Packer - Machine image build automation
Terraform - Infrastructure provisioning, infrastructure as code
Nomad - Cluster scheduler
Consul Connect - Service discovery, service configuration, service mesh
Vault - Centralized secrets manager
tags: Vagrant, Packer, Terraform, Consul, Nomad, Vault, HashiCorp, AWS, Azure, Multi-Cloud, Workflows, Automation

title: Building Confidence In Your Automated Tests
body: The growth of automation testing in today‚Äôs software development organizations is changing the the way we test applications. Software development practices have matured over the last 30 years, to include all forms of testing to verify software quality. In the last ten years, there has been a huge spike in the adoption of automated tests, effectively replacing some of these manual testing practices, and supplementing many traditional testing activities. Many parts of the software development industry, however, are wary of replacing manual testing with automated testing. Not only is there often a lack of confidence in the automation tests, many see automated testing as fragile, unmaintainable, and ultimately, something delivering a low return on investment. Max believes that by employing mature software development techniques, we can achieve robust, maintainable, tests, that deliver confidence of the application under test. In addition to discussing how to structure automated tests that are cleaner, more maintainable and efficient, developer testing, and deployment techniques can be used to programmatically verify test correctness. Drawing on his experiences building test automation, test frameworks and advising organizations to adopt test automation, Max will walk us through how to mature your test automation practices.
tags: Software Testing, Automation

title: Handling Customer Feedback
body:
For every new feature comes a new feature request, or so it would seem once a software project has more than a handful of users or "customers". In this talk we'll examine sources of customer feedback, ways to collect and curate it, and talk about how to balance the wisdom of the crowd vs. well-intentioned product direction. While I can't tell you what percentage of your time should be spent on bugs vs. new things, I can give you an understanding of what this space looks like at scale: direct from the owner of the customer feedback process at GitHub.

With examples coming from a well-known product like GitHub, my hope is that the audience will be able to draw parallels to their own experiences regardless of the size of their project. We will talk about things that have gone well and things that have not and the lessons we learned from it over the last 5 years at GitHub. We will take a deep dive into what happens when you don't do a good job of listening to customers and compare that to the behaviors of a project that has become customer obsessed. 

Finally, we've been through a lot of iterations of how best to handle customer feedback. We'll talk about the things you can do on the cheap and the type of stuff that makes sense at larger scale (aka, it'll cost ya). We'll also talk about the ideal state, which includes some thoughts and opportunities that currently sound good on paper but haven't been tested in our own crucible of enterprise and open source experience. 

The ultimate goal is to give you all some ideas of how to handle feedback for your own project or projects while giving you a little reassurance that it's OK to not totally nail this area. It's hard to do well and there's no such thing as permanent perfection. At the end of the day, handling customer feedback is all about empathy and giving it the best shot you can with the resources you have makes you a better technologist and builder of things. It's the thought that counts and a little execution goes a long way toward giving someone a better day!
tags: GitHub, product management, customer feedback, prioritization

title: Company Culture:  Evolving it, Not Creating/Maintaining it
body:
When companies start paying attention to company culture they tend to focus on how to create or maintain it.  You'll hear discussions about if interview candidates might adapt to the current culture.  Efforts will be made to weed out those who do not fit in with how things are perceived as working for the team now.  

This is toxic and destructive to the long term success of the team, company, and most importantly the individuals.

The dynamic of how people within any group interact is an organic, evolving thing that should never and can never remain static.  Culture is not a zero-sum game where people can be added or subtracted to reach an ideal, finite point.

We'll go over:

- why culture should not be seen as something to create or maintain
- different perspectives and techniques to reframe how you view and evaluate your company dynamic
- ways to shift your interview and performance review mindset towards promoting healthy dynamics and providing growth in the areas that need attention

title: Leveraging Kubevirt and Kubernetes as a training platform
body: As organizations look to keep up with an always evolving tech landscape, being able to easily run workshops and developing proof-of-concepts on a particular technology can become a critical utility in keeping a teams skills up to date or getting new members onboard. However this pipeline that you depend on can quickly become a nightmare due to the cost of maintenance in order to keep up with the changing variables of the teams you are working with (cloud environment, local policies, etc.). In this session, we will demonstrate how focusing on Kubevirt in conjunction with Kubernetes as your workshop platform can allow you to spend less time worrying about where and how you are going to dive in on new technical content for the purpose of workshops, PoCs and Testing - allowing you to shift your focus to what may matter more - your actual content. .
tags: Kubernetes, Kubevirt, Containers, Virtual Machines

title: ARCore Parkour: Building your first Augmented Reality app
body:
Today there are lots of case studies for Spatial Computing (Augmented Reality, Virtual Reality, Mixed Reality etc) in education and entertainment. Unfortunately, the newly released ARCore features like Augmented Images still lack tutorials and practical examples.  

In this interactive session, Noble Ackerson, a seasoned Technical Product Lead and GDE, shares insights with examples through a fun "choose your own adventure" technical talk (Bandersnatch-style), on how to build marker-based AR with Augmented Images to create experiences to transform data from the world into practical utility for your users.
tags: Augmented Reality, AR, AR Foundations, ARKit, ARCore

title: One Codebase to Rule Them All - Using React Native Everywhere
body: With React Native and tools like React Native Web, React Native Dom, and React XP it is possible to share nearly all of the same code between web, iOS, Android, and Windows apps. With the addition of Electron, that same codebase can be used to create Mac and Linux apps too! This talk will go through some of the leading approaches and provide real world examples of production apps using these technologies.
tags: react native, react, react xp, react native web, react native dom, javascript, mobile, desktop

title: Be the "Bootstrap":  Using Privilege to the Benefit of Others
body:
Recognizing privilege is a good first step towards the road to allyship for underrepresented groups, especially in software.  As with many things though, it is necessary but not sufficient for improving equity, inclusion, and acceptance.  In this talk, we'll discuss ways of using privilege and platform within your company to amplify the voices and presence of those who deserve it most, yet receive in the least.

A single talk cannot hope to fix or provide solutions to all the problems, but the goal is to provide actionable tools and resources to encourage communication, empathy, and further discussion in your team, company, and the software community as a whole.
tags: inclusion, diversity, equity, acceptance, visibility, voice, presence

title: Building Accessibility Together
body:
Accessibility can be a natural part of the design and development process that doesn‚Äôt sacrifice on looks or deadlines. 

Building an accessible product requires a team working together with intention, but it doesn‚Äôt require hours of pouring through intimidating technical standards. This talk shows how to incorporate accessibility best practices into your team‚Äôs workflow, from the beginning of a design kickoff through engineering implementation.

In this talk, we‚Äôll build an interactive search component from scratch and examine ways to collaborate, create effective handoff materials, implement accessible features, and test your work. With these guidelines, you‚Äôll be empowered to create accessible experiences with your team from start to finish.
tags: Accessibility, Design, HTML, CSS, Engineering, UX Design, UX Development, Collaboration, Teamwork, Workflows

title: How We Created and Then Worked to Disband A Risk Management Team
body: As our teams and traffic grew, CoverMyMeds experienced a series of deploy related incidents that ultimately lead to the institution of a heavy risk review roadblock for all production changes.  This new process was enforced by a volunteer team of developers.  In the beginning, it dramatically slowed delivery and frustrated or even angered us.  Over time, we improved both the process and the risk awareness of developers across the company.  After several iterations, we were able to return authority for risk management to the development teams and trusted that there would not be a backslide.  This talk explores the evolution of our pre-deploy risk management process and offers a case study of how we incorporated risk management into our culture so that a prescriptive review process and team to carry it out were no longer necessary.
tags: risk management, culture, growth, teams

title: Defending deep learning from adversarial attacks
body:
Adversarial examples in AI pose an asymmetrical challenge with respect to attackers and defenders. There is a need to empower AI developers to defend deep neural networks against adversarial attacks, and to allow rapid crafting and analysis of attack and defense methods for machine learning models.

In this talk we are going to discuss how to provide an implementation for many state-of-the-art methods for attacking and defending classifiers using open source Adversarial Robustness Toolbox. For AI developers, the library provides interfaces that support the composition of comprehensive defense systems using individual methods as building blocks.

In addition, using Jupyter notebook we will also show how to leverage attack methods from the Adversarial Robustness Toolbox (ART) into a model training pipeline on Fabric for Deep Learning (FfDL). This notebook trains a CNN model on the Fashion MNIST data set and the generated adversarial samples are used to evaluate the robustness of the trained model.
tags: deep learning, AI, adversarial attacks, adversarial defense

title: Testing Without Examples (with Examples): A Look at Property-Based Testing
body:
Have you ever heard of an example-based test? Chances are, you've written one without even knowing it! Every time we write a test where the input of the test is known, it's an example-based test.

Let's face it though, example-based tests can be hard to write. "Did I think of every possible edge case?" can be a tough question to answer. Sometimes we just don't know. Property-based tests are a great way to find those edge cases and can even help us fully understand how our code behaves under all conditions. Not just the ones we know about.

In this session, we'll learn all about the benefits (and drawbacks) of property-based testing through a series of examples using C# and FsCheck.
tags: testing, quality, unit testing

title: The four components of high performing teams.
body:
Do you have a great team & a great mission but don't understand why the pace of delivery is so slow? Architecture & tech stack is only one part of the story.
I believe high performing teams need four things to be effective:
Mastery - The skills & knowledge needed to do a great job, and a clear path to get to the next level.
Autonomy - The space to figure out their own solution to a problem & how they want to work
Purpose - A clear sense of direction, and the knowledge of how what they‚Äôre working on fits into the big picture & helps their team succeed.
Safety - A team that is afraid won‚Äôt take risks or experiment, a team that is afraid of finger-pointing won‚Äôt learn from mistakes.
In this talk I‚Äôll explain why those four things are key to teams being successful and give examples of how I‚Äôve turned teams around by fixing the lack of one or more of them.
tags: high performing teams, management, leadership

title: Who‚Äôs not in the room: Build better products by engaging hard to reach users
body:
As technologists, one of the hardest things to remember is that we‚Äôre not our users and our biases can easily extend into our work. Without thinking of who we are excluding, we might be building products designed only for people of a specific age, gender, ability and those with specific access to money, time and social network.

To make better products, we need our users to give us feedback every step of the way. In this talk, I‚Äôll share what my team and I learned from two different projects where we worked directly with our audiences- busy moms who were raising a child with autism and Gen Zs experiencing various forms of bullying. You‚Äôll learn what types of biases and points of exclusions to watch out for, how to engage hard-to-reach audiences, and how the user-driven insights we gained uncovered the struggles unique to their community and informed our design decisions and product iterations. Whether or not you work in UX design, this talk will help you create tech solutions that are physically, cognitively and emotionally accessible and ultimately valuable for all humans.
tags: user research, prototyping, inclusive design, products

title: Code Reviews? That's a Great Idea!
body:
We all know that code reviews are beneficial. We‚Äôve been told time and time again that they should be part of our development process. But ‚Äì like most best practices ‚Äì a practical implementation is challenging (and time consuming). Your team is convinced they are a great idea. You‚Äôll have an opportunity to squash bugs in the least costly of development times, learn new things from your talented teammates, and build a stronger foundation of trust. Awesome. Everyone is on board. But now what? What tools are out there? What are you actually looking for? How often should the reviews happen? What about bias?

In this talk, you‚Äôll get a practical guide to making code reviews effective. Whether you‚Äôre the reviewer or reviewee: there are ways to make sure this really is a great idea.
tags: development, soft-skills, code quality

title: Bringing order to chaos: incident management and your organization
body:
How well did you handle your company's last major system outage or service degradation? What did you do when you discovered an internal system or process was broken and you needed to fix it ASAP? If your company is like most, episodes like these trigger organizational panic and uncertainty about the best response. This is why you need organized incident management.

In this talk, you'll learn why Incident Management should be part of every organization's framework for handling emergent issues of all kinds. You'll walk away with a solid understanding of how you can approach your company's next technology or business crisis in a more productive and time-efficient way. Fundamentally, you'll learn the process for dealing with challenges for which there is no process.
tags: incident management, operations, leadership, trust

title: Deploy a Serverless Language Model
body: This session will serve as an introduction to using the AWS Serverless Application Model (SAM) as a method of deploying and hosting a machine learning API. Python‚Äôs PyTorch and FastAI libraries will be used for natural language processing predictions which will be easily triggered using HTTPS requests. During a live demonstration, a trained neural network model will be deployed from a remote Jupyter environment to S3. Separately a serverless application definition will be deployed from a local workstation using the SAM command line tool. Prediction requests will then be made using Postman. By seeing the workflow first hand, attendees will be able to build upon this example to deploy their own serverless applications and cost-effectively host custom trained machine learning models.
tags: fastai, pytorch, NLP, serverless, awssam, awslambda, apigateway python, machine-learning

title: Is CSS A Programming Language?
body:
CSS can be a source of deep frustration for developers, especially those most familiar with imperative languages such as JavaScript, Python, or Ruby. Over time, this has resulted in a portion of the web community with a fundamental misunderstanding of CSS ‚Äì not only of how to write it, but of what CSS is in the first place: a domain-specific, declarative programming language.

But, wait‚Ä¶CSS isn‚Äôt really programming language, is it? You can‚Äôt write algorithms in CSS‚Ä¶or can you?

Think again!
tags: css, programming languages, front-end, algorithms

title: Using accessibility as a bridge between design & development
body:
Web Accessibility is a team effort, but too often it is just viewed as a technical requirement relying only on the engineering team.
Unfortunately, you cannot deliver an accessible experience if the design and the project itself was not prepared for it.
In my last projects, I tried to use Web accessibility as a bridge between design & development and it worked.
New workflows, new deliverables, new rituals: focusing on making an accessible platform allowed my teams to abolish every wall between each specialties.
Let‚Äôs discuss together how we were able to do it and how we documented accessibility and shared accountability between PO, designers and engineers.
tags: accessibility, collaboration, team work, design, front-end engineering

title: Finding Happiness in Open Source
body:
As technologists have amazing skills and abilities, but for a lot of us the missing piece is finding a way to give back. Join me as I discuss how to get involved in open source helping organizations that support some of the most vulnerable members in our communities -- food banks, diaper banks, animal shelters, and many others. 

We'll also discuss the benefits, educational, personal and professional, of contributing to projects like these. You will leave having learned how to get involved in areas you‚Äôre passionate about to fill this missing piece that will keep you happy throughout your career.
tags: Open Source, Happiness, Doing Good, Making a Difference

title: How to build a community from scratch (while conquering social anxiety)
body:
How do you persuade people to join you in building a new community, especially when you have no idea what you're doing? I'll share my journey from socially anxious introvert with no technical background to founder of Learn Teach Code, the largest learning-focused tech meetup in Southern California with over 9,000 members.

The educational half of this talk: we'll explore how beginners can become mentors, how concepts from social science research can apply to tech communities, and how to recruit volunteers.

The personal half of this talk: I'll talk about community building as a form of social anxiety desensitization therapy, fighting depression by making new friends, and learning to code through peer-led, informal study groups.
tags: community building, leadership, social anxiety, mental health, social science, meetups, volunteerism

title: ‚ÄúTesting‚Äù - You keep using that word but I don‚Äôt think it means what you think it means!
body:
Do you find that you lack time and buy-in to write tests for your code?  Do you know exactly where you should spend your time testing?  Have you ever felt like you needed to create the entire architecture just to test a single feature?  Then this talk is for you!  Testing doesn‚Äôt have to feel like that last thing you have to do to meet acceptance criteria, it can actually be fun while ensuring quality for your application!  In a microservices world testing can actually get even simpler.  Inconceivable you say?  Not so.  

In this light-hearted, yet technical talk, Sam Brown, Director of Technology at Oteemo will make testing an approachable topic that will have you wondering why you haven‚Äôt been writing more tests! He will also break down how microservices architectures actually make testing easier, not more difficult.  The listener will leave with a solid appreciation for the Princess Bride as well as directly applicable strategies for simplifying testing approaches while increasing overall test coverage and quality.
tags: Testing, Microservices, Unit Tests, Integration Tests, Acceptance Tests

title: Negotiate Like a Badass
body:
Technical folx often don't negotiate, and when we do, we often undersell ourselves. Over the course of our careers, missed opportunities to ask for more financially can add up to a substantial loss. In this talk, I'll go over best practices for negotiating; highlight some key issues for women and under-represented minorities specifically; and address how to prepare for different types of negotiations. 

There will be some exercises to help audience members identify specific areas to practice or research in preparation for a possible upcoming negotiation.
tags: negotiations, professional development

title: Using Ansible and Terraform to avoid cloud lock-in
body: One of the main pitfalls of moving to the cloud is locking yourself in to a particular provider.  Tools like CloudFormation can rapidly provision environments for your applications but make moving your infrastructure to a a different provider or your own infrastructure a complex process.  Come hear about using Open Source automation tooling to make your workloads easily portable across both public and private clouds with a minimum of reconfiguration.  The demo will focus using Ansible and Terraform to deploy to both AWS and VMware vCloud Director environments but the best practices discussed will apply to just about any combination of tooling and infrastructure that makes sense for your application.
tags: automation, aws, vmware, ansible, terraform, vcloud director

title: It is correct but is it fast?
body:
Ruby is optimised for happiness, we tell ourselves when we write beautiful code. We‚Äôve written our acceptance and unit tests. What else is there to do? Nah, we don‚Äôt need to worry about performance. 

Sometimes, though, things turn sour when your beautiful code meets reality and the data processing consumes all of the server‚Äôs resources. There are no magic bullets that can instantly detect performance and scaling issues in our code, but there are techniques that can help. 

In this talk, you‚Äôll learn all about the benefits of writing performance assertions in a test suite. You‚Äôll see how a seemingly reasonable algorithm in fact exhibits abysmal performance and doesn‚Äôt scale. We‚Äôll explore two different types of performance assertions that can be used to establish the performance characteristics of our example. Once we‚Äôve done that, from then on, only hard cold measurements will guide us in refactoring the code to be more performant.

You will leave equipped with the techniques to help you learn how fast your code really is. Let‚Äôs put a stop to slow code and remove all of those pesky performance bugs!
tags: performance testing, testing,

title: Sextech: The Good, The Bad & The Bias
body:
When it comes to sextech, people often let their imaginations get in the way of the facts. One common reason is that the media likes to focus primarily on VR porn and bang-able robots. In reality these subjects are just a small uncommon sliver on the sextech spectrum. Sextech spans everything from menopause technology and sex-ed apps for teens to teledildonics and erotica audiobooks.

You encounter it when you use an app to track your menstrual cycle, talk to an A.I. OBGYN chatbot, or simply just watch pornography.

In this talk I'll describe:

‚Ä¢ briefly what sextech is

‚Ä¢ the current biases sextech faces and how they detrimentally impact marginalized groups, lead to sexual abuse and stifle innovation within the industry 

‚Ä¢ why sextech is the most lucrative sector of technology based on growth statistics, use-cases and the human experience.

‚Ä¢ why adding ‚Äútech" to the end of ‚Äúsex‚Äù gives us ‚Äúpermission‚Äù to start dialogue on a taboo topic. The tech sector is uniquely positioned to remove the stigma surrounding one of the most common human experiences, and this is important for eliminating the professional risk associated with working in sextech. Technology enables bright minds to come forward and provide real world solutions to things like human trafficking, STIs, sexual assault, sex-ed, and more.

‚Ä¢ why being informed on the subject will make you a more well-rounded inclusive technologist and advocate for a more diverse tech industry
tags: sextech, teledildonics, tech ethics, diversity and inclusion

title: Identity Expression: Coming Out of the Work Closet
body:
In companies all over, ‚Äòinclusion‚Äô and ‚Äòidentity‚Äô have become buzzwords. Declarations of acceptance are passed down from executive conference rooms, by way of internal emails and external job postings. In reality, an inclusive work environment isn‚Äôt a box to be checked off, a message to be marked as read, or a motivational poster hung by a water cooler. It takes effort across the board, throughout all levels of a workplace to create a space where everyone feels welcome.

There are concrete advantages to an inclusive company culture, including increased productivity, creativity, and collaboration. In industries like design, engineering, technology, and management, those three facets can be the difference between being at the top of your field, or the bottom of the pack, so what employer wouldn‚Äôt want every worker to be feeling and performing at their best?

As a gay man, I have a personal stake in encouraging each and every company I come in contact with to consider the identity expression of their employees. More specifically, as a gay man in the south, I‚Äôve had plenty of experience working in places that have been less than opening and accepting. In some positions, a portion of my energy that could have otherwise been dedicated to my job, instead went to staying in the ‚Äúwork-closet,‚Äù despite my proudly being out to friends and family for years at the time. I caught myself ‚Äústraightening up‚Äù my wardrobe, removing nail polish from my fingers, and changing gender pronouns when coworkers probed about my dating life. From time to time, I‚Äôd be extremely conscious of peers that would react negatively if they knew I was gay. Often, I was unsure whether people would care or not. But if it‚Äôs not clear whether a company‚Äôs culture genuinely supports people of all kinds of identities, it‚Äôs consequently easier for people of marginalized communities to suppress who they are to some degree. 

It wasn‚Äôt until I found a job at a company that champions diversity and personal identity, that I realized I had silently wandered my way back into a closet. Over time, I realized that many of my coworkers had their own closets, even those outside of communities you typically hear about in conversations about inclusivity. They changed the way they spoke, avoided conversations around religious practices and holidays, and removed piercings and covered tattoos with foundation or long sleeves.  Identity concealment had been slipped into morning routines, somewhere between the first cup of coffee and last red light before pulling into the parking lot. 

Historically, the groups most affected by this are those belonging to marginalized communities. There‚Äôs been a long history of discrimination and mistreament on the basis of race, gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation, and gender expression in the workplace. Although we‚Äôve made great strides forward over the past century by way of workplace equality, we‚Äôre still not there. For example, as of 2018, it‚Äôs still legal to be fired from your job in 30 states, solely for being a member of the LGBTQ+ community. Even if you work for a company in a state with protections, there‚Äôs always a level of uncertainty about how people may react to your true identity. In my case, concealment became a defense mechanism. Because of it, I wasn‚Äôt at my best. I know that I may just be one single employee, but if every historically marginalized group falls victim to identity concealment at some point or another, the numbers increase exponentially. 4.5% of the US population identifies as queer. 39% identify as a racial or ethnic minority. 51% identify as female. This is a bigger issue than one person, one company, or one state. 

This talk highlights the opportunities of individual employees at all levels of a company or organization to make their work lives better. Diversity, inclusion, and identity expression can make or break company culture. Shortcomings in diversity diminish productivity, creativity, and collaboration. A lack of consideration of how safe, welcome, and accepted your employees feel can have far reaching consequences, but it‚Äôs not just about people feeling comfortable. It‚Äôs about making sure that a portion of the energy they could devote to their jobs, doesn‚Äôt go to changing the name of the person they‚Äôre dating. It doesn‚Äôt go towards second guessing conversations with coworkers, or towards prevented conversations in the first place. It‚Äôs so that energy, that effort, that focus, can help propel your company and workplace forward with all of your employees fully on board. There are tangible benefits to enacting efforts around identity expression and inclusion at work. Being a diverse and open workplace is just good business.
tags: Inclusion, Diversity, LGBTQ, Minorities, Equality, Design, Creativity, Engineering, Teamwork, Culture, Collaboration, Community

title: The Differences and Benefits of Teaching High School Computer Science (WIP Title)
body:
How did you learn to code? Chances are it was not in high school. Only 35% of high schools teach computer science in the country. Yet computing jobs are the number one source of new wages, and the US has roughly 500,000 open positions. So how we can help solve this problem?

TEALS is one organization dedicated to bringing Computer Science to every high school. They connect tech professionals to high schools in need, who assist in CS education. But teaching in a high school environment is different than mentoring a junior engineer. This talk will dive into how you can volunteer, learn to teach, and teach to learn. As a bonus, we will also discuss how students can learn source control, and share their work with the world.
tags: education,teaching,mentoring,computer science,diversity,communication

title: Write Code In Production
body: Teams building data-oriented applications against sensitive or large-scale information often face the problem of how to conduct discovery and work iteratively during development. Often, developers are cut-off from production data sets for security and operational reasons. But this doesn't have to be the case. You can build your system in such a way that analysts can work securely with production data, separate from customers, sharing their work, and performing quality control with real, live, production data. Save on operational overhead and complexity while maintaining security by moving your development environment to production instead of your production environment to your laptop.
tags: security, privacy, data science, software engineering, software architecture

title: Evolving Ingress/v1beta1
body:
The Ingress object was added to Kubernetes in version 1.2 to describe properties of a cluster-wide reverse HTTP proxy. Since that time, it has not progressed beyond the beta stage, and its stagnation inspired an explosion of annotations to express missing properties of HTTP routing. 

In order to support a real-world ingress platform, a new Ingress CRD, named IngressRoute, aims to solve these missing properties as well as support multi-team clusters with the ability to limit the management of routes to specific virtual hosts. This delegation pattern allows for powerful ingress traffic manipulation across teams and reduces errors due to bad configuration.

Come see how a fresh perspective to ingress traffic can allow your teams to self-manage their application connectivity; as well as have a fully featured API spec to code against.
tags: Kubernetes, DevOps, Application Deployments

title: Machines as Artists: Making Music with Neural Networks
body:
For a long time, we‚Äôve been thinking about computer science as a tool for automation and computation. With the recent rise in popularity of artificial intelligence, researchers have started experimenting with using it for more artistic and creative applications.

In the first part of the talk, you‚Äôll hear about an overview of the different tools that were developed to use machine learning to generate music, such as Google Magenta, MuseGAN, and MidiNet. With architectures from Variational Autoencoders (VAE) to Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM); different tools are applied on different music data types, from raw audio files (e.g. mp3 files) to midi sequences. 

The second part of the talk will walk you through how you can get started to work on this problem, create your own LSTM in a few steps, and understand many of the consideration of how music generation differers from other time-series-based applications of machine learning.
tags: machine learning, artificial intelligence, music, art, neural networks

title: Starting a mentorship program without any money
body:
Whenever we have already started our own career in software, we forget how hard were the first steps. Some big companies have the resources to train students to work for them, paying them for their time. Still, whenever you are part of a smaller organization you don't have the funds for anything like that. That's why you need to leverage on some other aspect to help young developers have real-life experience and find their first job.
In this talk, you'll learn how to set up a sustainable framework to benefit all three parts involved in the mentorship process: the apprentices, the mentors, and the community. If you want to give back, empower new colleagues or have fun with new projects, you can't miss this talk.
tags: mentorship, opportunities, job, education, career development

title: The Next Billion Users and the Digital Gender Divide
body:
By the end of 2019, about half of the global population will be online. In many parts of the world, however, internet access is strikingly disparate by gender, preventing women from accessing modern technology. In a world where we access our money, education, and crucial information about daily life from the internet, promoting equal access to the web is key to promoting gender equality on all levels.

In this session, we‚Äôll dive into where the next billion users are and what their lives are like, how these users are getting online, and how internet access is a gender equality issue. On the way, we‚Äôll talk about how to design and develop for global users, since these next billion users will soon be key for any global company‚Äôs future strategy.
tags: global internet, gender equality, web development

title: 12 Factor Serverless Applications
body: The ‚ÄúTwelve-Factor‚Äù application model has come to represent twelve best practices for building modern, cloud-native applications. With guidance on things like configuration, deployment, runtime, and multiple service communication, the Twelve-Factor model prescribes best practices that apply to everything from web applications to APIs to data processing applications. Although serverless computing and AWS Lambda have changed how application development is done, the ‚ÄúTwelve-Factor‚Äù best practices remain relevant and applicable in a serverless world. In this talk, we‚Äôll apply the ‚ÄúTwelve-Factor‚Äù model to serverless application development with AWS Lambda and Amazon API Gateway and show you how these services enable you to build scalable, well built, and low administration applications.
tags: Serverless, 12 Factor, API gateway, Lambda

title: metal2docker: Taking Software as a Service Microservices Architectures Beyond the Cloud and Into the On-Prem Enterprise Environment.
body:
On-prem enterprise software deserves the benefits of CI/CD as much as their cloud-based counterparts. Continuous automatic software updates on autonomous on-prem systems which the software developer has very little control over is now made easier with the use of containers within a microservices architectures. This is how SAAS is made possible on-prem.

In this talk we describe a methodology for converting enterprise on-prem single-server software architectures to fully containerized microservices architectures. We go through different architectural components and show how they can be containerized by converting their bare metal configurations into a combination of Dockerfiles, configuration templates, environment variable files and scripts. 

Moreover, we describe how to build a set of accompanying metal2docker containers which will automatically transform every service on every on-prem deployment of the software, into a containerized one which can be self-upgraded to future versions of the software's microservices architecture. 

We also show specific examples of how we did this for services like mysql, redis, ruby and node.js.

We create a complete production software release with a self-upgrading system which depends on a set of cloud repositories to handle software releases or even off-line upgrades. Specialized micro services are used to handle the software updates. The self updating system is also capable of maintaining the software's host, upgrading the docker daemon and reconfiguring the docker network to match the customer's enterprise network configuration using another set of microservices.
tags: On-prem, containers, docker, software architecture, deployment, SaaS

title: Programming Language: Learning to Present, Talk, and Ask Questions in an Inclusive Way
body: As our tech communities grow more aware of the need to and value of being inclusive and welcoming in our approach, many people still struggle with how to amend their vocabulary and style of speaking to reflect their desire to really be inclusive. The causes for this are many but often include cognitive biases, and a lack of understanding about how to speak in a way that will entice others to hear and listen to what we're saying, and a misunderstanding on how importance words and phrases are to humans. This talk will explore the value of saying things in such a way so as to build inclusivity and connection between people. The talk will provide tools and language attendees can immediately implement to foster greater sense of welcome and community.
tags: diversity, inclusion, communication, language

title: Harnessing data at the intersection of society and culture
body:
City agencies rely on outdated data technology and lack data-standardization. This makes it costly and time consuming for developers to create tools for cities to harness the utility of data for service delivery policy development. 

This talk will discuss a project in which Census data is used as a tool for urban planning. As neighborhoods are categorized as ‚Äúgentrified‚Äù and low-income residents are displaced, policy interventions become costly and unmanageable. Forecasting problems around urbanization and economic development fuels long-term planning efficiency, while reducing costs and delivering better value to communities. 

Secondly, as the social sector begins to adopt data technologies, developers must be committed to data equality and data representation. This means harnessing the power of data for social change with the understanding that behind every data point is a human with complex behavior and unique interaction with systems.

title: XXS Primer
body: Cross-site scripting (XSS) is a code injection attack that allows an attacker to execute malicious JavaScript in another user's browser. The attacker's primary target are other users of an application.  XXS scripting is frequently exploited for illegitimate ad injection including click fraud, exploitation frameworks (such as BeEF) to attack the victim‚Äôs system from within the browser context, and bitcoin mining. This talk will demonstrate how various forms of these attacks succeed and what web developers can do to prevent them using input validation, Content Security Policy (CSP), and the Trusted Types experimental API.
tags: Cross-site scripting, XSS, Content Security Policy, Trusted Types, Secure Web Development, Software Security

title: Celebrating 30 Years and Enhancing the Web Commons
body:
In the past 30 years, the Web Platform has come to enable so much of our modern world. We're all familiar with the most obvious examples, but did you know the Web Platform has been used to create phone applications, games, art, billboards, kiosks, print, television, automobile and appliance interfaces? 

In this talk, I'll show how pervasive and fundamental the use of web technologies is, and why it's important to protect the commons of the Web Platform. I will present the interesting history of shrewd decisions, happy accidents, struggles and wrong turns that led us to this point.

Then, we'll take a look at the complex realities of standards work today. How can we tend the Web Platform to keep it flourishing for another 30 years and beyond? What do we need to be prioritizing right now? And how can you get involved from the trenches of web development?
tags: web, standardization, community, history, commons

title: Humane Tech: Redefining the Relationship with Pervasive Technology
body:
This talk will orient around my efforts to change and re-orient my relationship to technology, with special attention paid to social media, streaming media (i.e., YouTube, Netflix), and tools to measure and assess technology use. My personal experience will be used to segue into personal evaluation of tech use, and how the user/technology relationship can become more complementary, rather than consumptive. It is NOT about quitting one's smartphone, but rather, using technology in a way that enhances, rather than detracts, from daily life. 

The structure of the talk will include 5 sections:
- Defining and explaining 'humane technology' and why it matters
- An exploration of how different platforms (especially Facebook, Twitter, and Google) use hyper-targeted user data to segment and engage users
- The starting point: an honest look at my own idle smartphone use ... and what prompted me to change
- Tools and data: apps used to measure time spent in different apps, identifying triggers, and physical interventions ('sleeping bag' for phones)
- First-pass efforts: how successful was I? What happened as a result? Where do I/we go from here?
tags: humane technology, technology ethics, work-life balance

title: Mosaic Theory of Information Security
body:
In finance, a concept called mosaic theory says that non-material information in sufficient quantities can be combined to constitute useful information. Investment analysts using this principle combine non-material information to develop significant insights into companies‚Äô upcoming results without verging into insider trading. 

In other words, a lot of insignificant details, like you might post to social media, can be combined to deduce significant aspects of your or your organization‚Äôs private data. In non-financial information security, a similar principle applies. Small divergences from usual patterns can, when combined together, give a competitor or potential attacker hints about your organization‚Äôs strategy, upcoming product launches, or your private personal information. 

In this talk, we discuss types of information you want to avoid posting about yourself or watch out for in your organization‚Äôs social media postings to avoid unintentional disclosures.
tags: information security, mosaic theory, finance, privacy
